terms.definition: A legal agreement outlining terms under which one party agrees to rent property from another, typically for 6-12 months.
terms.example: A 12-month lease in {{STATE_NAME}} specifying ${{STATE_MEDIAN_RENT}}/month rent, pet policies, and maintenance responsibilities

terms.definition: The difference between a property's current market value and the amount still owed on the mortgage‚Äîyour ownership stake.
terms.example: Home worth ${{STATE_MEDIAN_HOME_PRICE}} with $350K mortgage = significant equity (your net worth in the property)

terms.definition: A loan used to purchase a home where the property itself serves as collateral, typically repaid over 15-30 years.
terms.example: A 30-year fixed mortgage at {{STATE_AVG_MORTGAGE_RATE}}% means consistent monthly payments for 360 months

terms.definition: An annual tax paid by homeowners based on the assessed value of their property, used to fund local services.
terms.example: In {{STATE_NAME}}, property tax averages {{STATE_PROPERTY_TAX_AVG}}% of home value annually

leftPanel.title: Financial Aspects of Renting
paragraphs: Renting involves paying a property owner for the right to live in their property for a specific period governed by a lease agreement.
Monthly costs include: Rent payment, renter's insurance ($15-30/mo), utilities, and sometimes parking.
Upfront costs: Security deposit (1-2 months' rent) and first month's rent‚Äîtypically $3,000-$5,000 total in {{STATE_NAME}}.

highlightBox.text: � Renters are NOT responsible for major repairs, property taxes, or maintenance‚Äîthe landlord covers these costs.

leftColumn.title: � Renting
items: Flexibility to move when lease ends

leftPanel.title: Financial Aspects of Owning
paragraphs: Owning means purchasing property with a mortgage loan, giving you full rights as long as you maintain payments.
Monthly costs include: Mortgage (principal + interest), property taxes, homeowner's insurance, HOA fees (if applicable), and maintenance.
Upfront costs: Down payment (3-20% of ${{STATE_MEDIAN_HOME_PRICE}}) plus closing costs (2-5%).

highlightBox.text: � Each mortgage payment builds equity‚Äîyour ownership stake grows over time as you pay down the loan.

layoutData.title: What Should Guide Your Housing Choice?
paragraphs: The rent vs. buy decision is deeply personal and depends on multiple interconnected factors. There's no universally "right" answer‚Äîonly what's right for your specific situation in {{STATE_NAME}}.
bulletPoints: Financial Readiness: Savings for down payment, credit score, stable income, emergency fund
Time Horizon: How long you plan to stay (generally need 5+ years to make buying worthwhile)
Career Stability: Job security, potential relocations, remote work flexibility
Local Market: {{STATE_NAME}}'s price-to-rent ratio, appreciation trends, market conditions
Lifestyle Preferences: Desire to customize, willingness to handle maintenance
Family Plans: Growing family may need more space and stability

content.headerTitle: Why This Matters for Your Future

layoutData.title: Housing = Your Largest Expense
paragraphs: Housing is typically the largest expense you'll face in your lifetime. Whether you rent or buy in {{STATE_NAME}}, this decision significantly impacts your financial situation, lifestyle, and long-term wealth building potential.
bulletPoints: Monthly Budget: Housing should ideally be under 28-30% of gross income
Wealth Building: Homeowners have 40x higher net worth than renters (median)
Retirement Security: Owning a paid-off home reduces retirement expenses dramatically
Flexibility vs. Stability: Your life stage determines which matters more
Opportunity Cost: Money spent on housing can't be invested elsewhere
{{STATE_NAME}} Market: Local conditions affect which option makes more sense

leftPanel.title: Current Housing Reality
paragraphs: Today's housing market presents unique challenges for young adults. Rising prices, higher interest rates, and limited inventory have made homeownership increasingly difficult.
Many successful financial strategies now include renting while investing the difference‚Äîsometimes outperforming homeownership in high-cost markets.
The key is making an informed decision based on your specific circumstances in {{STATE_NAME}}, not following outdated rules or social pressure.

highlightBox.text: � Housing needs change over time. The right choice today might be different five years from now.

scenario.name: Amy's Smart Renting Decision in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Amy is a 25-year-old software developer who recently started her career in {{STATE_NAME}}. She chose to rent an apartment near downtown for ${{STATE_MEDIAN_RENT}}/month, close to her workplace and entertainment options.

Her reasoning: As a young professional, Amy values flexibility to accept job opportunities in different locations. Instead of saving for a down payment, she invests the difference in her 401(k) and index funds.
Monthly breakdown: ${{STATE_MEDIAN_RENT}} rent + $20 renter's insurance + $150 utilities = approximately ${{STATE_MEDIAN_RENT}} + $170/month total

scenario.name: John & Maria's Homeownership in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: John and Maria, a married couple in their 30s with stable careers in {{STATE_NAME}}, purchased a home at the median price of ${{STATE_MEDIAN_HOME_PRICE}} with a 10% down payment and closing costs.

Their reasoning: With established careers and plans to start a family, they wanted stability and the ability to build equity. A fixed-rate mortgage at {{STATE_AVG_MORTGAGE_RATE}}% gives them predictable payments.
